GAH THIS VIDEO WAS SO GOOD, like literally, how insane is it do just conceive of the very thought of how we even see and process these things. Millions and millions and cells are working in unison, so intimately and so instantly, that all the work they do in a split-second gives us the a fleeting experience with the seemingly-simple power of sight. Let alone, just thinking of how we are even able to discuss and think about this at all is insane. Makes me seriously appreciate just the literal experience of existing at all, and makes things like seeing colors all the more precious and privileged to even have. I wish our societies (aka governments/humanity in general) could just stop fighting and searching for more power, and instead work together to do things that can really benefit humanity. Like, imagine the technology we could make in the future to help people have better lives and have more meaningful experiences with the world and each other.

3:50 dababy

I'm actually watching this video using glasses with two differently colored lenses. One is golden and the other is purple. This enables me to see a range of 'new' colors that I've never seen before. For example: True Cyan. It bugs me that you didn't include cyan as it's own color and wavelenght at around 1:00. Because to me - especially with the aforementioned glasses - Cyan is a very strong and vibrant color. I can also see real blurple, a blue that is also a red-purple and almost makes it's very own color. And I can see a magenta/fuchsia with these glasses that's so vibrant and full of color that whenever I saw this color in flowers I just stood there for minutes to admire it. Furthermore, I can differentiate a lot more charteuse colors with the gold/purple glasses on. When looking at Concetta Anticos (first functional tetrachromat identified) paintings I really get what she may see. Without the gold/purple they are just normal paintings. But with the glasses on, it's a whole different world of color. There are many more colors to be explored with glasses that have two differently colored lenses. But the gold/purple one is by far the best for experiencing new colors; and I've tried many color combinations.

Why do you say "people who identify as men/women"? Women have XX chromosomes and men have XY. A woman who identifies as a man cannot have XY chromosomes. She will still have only XX. Similarly, a man who identifies as a woman will also not have XX chromosomes but XY instead no matter what he does. Political correctness is irrelevant in science.

I have excellent color vision for a man. I can pinpoint a greater variety of reds, greens, and yellows, than most men I know. Even in the design field.

However, I can never claim to be tetrachromtic because I do not have the chromosomes for it. It just means I have no perceptable color blindness.

The reason women can be tetrachromtic is because they have two X chromosomes. Each chromosome determines the blue and green cones. However, if the green cones determined by one of the X chromosomes is "defective", the green may be more "yellow" when compared to the other one. That is why tetrochramtic women often see more yellow wavelengths then non-tetrachromtic people. If they are perceptive to thier tetrachromacy, they can see and point out far more shades of yellow, red, and green than I can.

Essentially, the same defect which causes colorblindness in men gives women the ability to see more color do to have two sets of blue and green cones.

The human retina can actually detect even shorter wavelengths, down to about 300, which is firmly in the 'UV' range. It's the lens of the eye that absorbs these wavelengths that makes them invisible to most people. However, people without natural lens in their eyes, and a rare few with slightly different makeup of lens, can see UV light.
Some artists have described the color as a white-blue, others as black-purple. It looks like UV, any unless you're one of the few who can see it, it can't really be accurately described.

i don't think its that men can't see specific colors compared to women, its that we don't see the point of remembering the names of every shade of a specific color. for us we know the basic colors then the different shades of those colors and we just call them dark or light versions of said colors. I'm not gonna memorize the name of every shade of red, I googled the names and there's 20
red, cherry, rose, jam, merlot, garnet, crimson, ruby, scarlet, etc. etc. you know what most men would call those shades of red?
"red, dark red, light red, or pink if its light enough. we can see the different shades perfectly but we just don't think they are different enough to care to identify them by their own names.
I'm sure its important for color reasons for decorating or identifying types of plants or scientific, or artistic reasons, etc. but since most men don't really deal with shades of colors often enough to need to know every shades name, we just call them by their primary colors names and put a qualifier like "light/dark" if they are slightly different from the primary color or add "ish" when its mixed with another color like "blueish green" its an easier system when trying to describe a color we see.
I'm sure men can see the same color spectrum as women, just remembering all the names isn't necessary for our survival so we don't bother to learn it unless we need to. most of us men aren't dealing with the world in a way were we have to differentiate these shades and identify them accordingly.

For anyone wondering, the 4th cone that some women can see is yellow. You can't test for it using a screen since most screens project images using RGB light, so it has to be tested for in person.

I gotta say though, there's nothing like being in an art class and everyone talking about how deep and pure red something was when it was clearly yellow orange to me. I got a color test done later to see if I was missing any cones and got a 100% on all colors, so I definitely wasn't missing something. I later found out that some women can see more yellow than others because they have cones for it, and it all fell into place.

actually the color wheel is not a description of the physics of light but how our visual neural nets work. in physics, color isn't circular but linear. after blue/violet comes ultra violet etc. until gamma rays and before red theres infrared etc. until radio waves and other super low frequencies. unlike in our vision, there is no purple and magenta. these are red and blue light waves hitting our eyes at the same time. on the color wheel, it's the colours between red and blue, which don't exist physically. there is no complementary color in physics, just in our brain.

I call BS on some people seeing “100x more colors” (6:11)
If people see 380nm to 700nm then just 2x more color would be +320nm added to that range. Then there are illusion colors such as magenta, and while adding another color detector would increase the countable “fake” colors; it still wouldn’t be 100x more.
We can see uv light but our lens filter it out.
